full_summary:
Janitorial Services Contract at MCTS Centre, Placentia, NL
**Solicitation Number:** 30003452
**Issue Date:** December 22, 2022
**Closing Date:** January 23, 2023, 14:00:00

**Procurement Category:** SRV (Services)
**Procurement Method:** Competitive – Open Bidding
**Trade Agreements:** Canada-Chile Free Trade Agreement (CCFTA), Canada-Panama Free Trade Agreement, Canada-Peru Free Trade Agreement (CPFTA), Canada-Korea Free Trade Agreement (CKFTA), Canada-Honduras Free Trade Agreement, and Canadian Free Trade Agreement (CFTA)

**Contracting Entity:** Fisheries and Oceans Canada
**Contact Information:**
- Martin Larocque, Contract Engineer
- Phone: 819-454-2077
- Email: martin.larocque@dfo-mpo.gc.ca

**Objective:** This requirement is for the provision of janitorial services at the Marine Communications and Traffic Services (MCTS) Centre, Placentia, Newfoundland and Labrador.

**Scope of Work:**
The scope involves the provision of all Cleaning and Maintenance Services at the MCTS Centre. The area includes:
– Main Building (785 sq.m)
– Office Areas
– Electronics Workshop
– Board Room
– Shower Room
– Main Operations Room
– Janitors Closets
– Lift
– Other Common Areas

**Work Schedule:** The services will be required 5 days a week, from Monday to Friday, inclusive.

**Security Requirement:** All personnel having security clearance must hold a valid Reliability Status granted or approved by CISD/PWGSC.

**Contract Period:** From the contract award date to December 31, 2026.

**Notification:** The crown reserves the right to negotiate with any supplier on any procurement. Documents may be submitted in either official language (English or French).

**Tender Documents:** Available at the Government of Canada Electronic Tendering Service (BUYANDSELL.GC.CA) or on the Public Works and Government Services Canada Website, under Tender Number 30003452.
---

Here is what I changed:
- **Formatting:** Moved all relevant information to Stress Bomed headings to improve readability.
- **Language:** Sourced and homogenized messages; ensured all text took advantage of 400-words limit while omitting colloquialisms and excessive detail (Although including the essential materials as asked.).
Eliminated extraneous pieces of text and networking
